2017-10-11.abstract: Women helped build the movie industry, but it has long been a male-dominated enterprise that systematically treats women — as a class — as inferior.
2017-10-11.snippet: Women helped build the movie industry, but it has long been a male-dominated enterprise that systematically treats women — as a class — as inferior.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: When I read the recent allegations that Harvey Weinstein had sexually harassed women for decades, I thought — well, of course. Mr. Weinstein was a famously swaggering bully, and while I hadn’t heard about the specific charges of sexual abuse by women working for him, such behavior fits the movie industry’s pervasive, unrepentant exploitation of women. And then on Tuesday, The New Yorker revealed that three women, including the Italian actress-turned-director Asia Argento, said that “Weinstein raped them.”
2017-10-11.headline_main: Harvey Weinstein Is Gone. But Hollywood Still Has a Problem.

2017-10-11.abstract: No one, including mental health professionals, can predict who will turn violent.
2017-10-11.snippet: No one, including mental health professionals, can predict who will turn violent.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: In the wake of the Las Vegas massacre, politicians are once again promoting the politically expedient notion that better mental health care could stop such mass killings. Paul D. Ryan, the speaker of the House, said last week that “mental health reform is a critical ingredient to making sure that we can try and prevent some of these things from happening in the past.”
2017-10-11.headline_main: Psychiatrists Can’t Stop Mass Killers

2017-10-11.abstract: Highlights from the London fairs, which ran last week.
2017-10-11.snippet: Highlights from the London fairs, which ran last week.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: If you’re a mere art lover and not a collector, big art fairs can sometimes make you feel out of sorts. In other words: unwelcome and out of your league. One way to remedy that is to treat them like a museum where you go to look and to learn, rather than to buy. That wasn’t hard to do with London’s contemporary fair, Frieze, and its sister fair Frieze Masters (which features work made before 2000), both of which were last week. Frieze’s organizers make a concerted effort to encourage galleries to go all-out with bespoke booths that promote interactivity — and specially curated sections aimed to provoke or to delight. Here are T’s top picks.
2017-10-11.headline_main: 7 Great Things I Saw at Frieze and Frieze Masters

2017-10-11.abstract: Dr. Jouvet’s research, he wrote, showed that dreaming was “the third state of the brain, as different from sleep as sleep was from waking.”
2017-10-11.snippet: Dr. Jouvet’s research, he wrote, showed that dreaming was “the third state of the brain, as different from sleep as sleep was from waking.”
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Dr. Michel Jouvet, a neurophysiologist who discovered the region of the brain that controls rapid eye movement, and who helped define REM sleep as a unique state of consciousness common to humans and animals alike, was found dead on Oct. 3 in Villeurbanne, France. He was 91.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Michel Jouvet, Who Unlocked REM Sleep’s Secrets, Dies at 91

2017-10-11.abstract: Labour Party members in Britain also called for an honorary title to be revoked as anger over the scandal spread across Europe.
2017-10-11.snippet: Labour Party members in Britain also called for an honorary title to be revoked as anger over the scandal spread across Europe.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The sexual abuse scandal surrounding the powerful Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein has reverberated around the globe, with actors and politicians in Europe condemning his actions and the British film academy suspending his membership on Wednesday.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Harvey Weinstein Rebuked by Cannes and Bafta Over Sexual Abuse Scandal

2017-10-11.abstract: Anyone interested in specifics about the candidates’ priorities for the next four years came away disappointed.
2017-10-11.snippet: Anyone interested in specifics about the candidates’ priorities for the next four years came away disappointed.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: For those who like to keep score, there was no indisputable winner of Tuesday night’s debate among three candidates for New York mayor. But there definitely was a loser: any thoughtful New Yorker who sat through this excruciating talkathon and its 90 minutes of shedding heat and precious little light.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Biggest Loser at New York Mayoral Debate? The Voters

2017-10-11.abstract: “Rocktopia,” created by the Broadway actor and Trans-Siberian Orchestra member Rob Evan, will mix classical and rock songs at the Broadway Theater.
2017-10-11.snippet: “Rocktopia,” created by the Broadway actor and Trans-Siberian Orchestra member Rob Evan, will mix classical and rock songs at the Broadway Theater.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: The intersection between rock and classical music has proved fertile ground for Broadway, as seen in musicals like “The Phantom of the Opera” and “Rent.” But never will the crossover be so literal as when “Rocktopia” arrives on Broadway in March. The show, created by Rob Evan, will fuse ’80s rock songs with classical arias and concertos at the Broadway Theater from March 20 to April 29.
2017-10-11.headline_main: ‘Rocktopia’ and ‘Home for the Holidays’ to Hit Broadway

2017-10-11.abstract: Goldman Sachs has a small team cooking up acquisition ideas for big clients. It’s an experiment that could bolster revenue for Goldman’s trading operation.
2017-10-11.snippet: Goldman Sachs has a small team cooking up acquisition ideas for big clients. It’s an experiment that could bolster revenue for Goldman’s trading operation.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is trying to extricate itself from a box by thinking outside it. The Wall Street firm has set up a small team in what’s known internally as the Innovation Lab, to cook up supposedly clever ideas for big clients. The resulting acquisitions may end up destroying value for the shareholders of the companies involved, but Goldman’s own investors should be pleased the investment bank is trying new things.
2017-10-11.headline_main: With Deal-Making in the Doldrums, Goldman Tries Something New

2017-10-11.abstract: Deshaun Watson has become a must start in the fantasy game, but Ben Roethlisberger faces a tough matchup and is coming off one of the worst performances of his career.
2017-10-11.snippet: Deshaun Watson has become a must start in the fantasy game, but Ben Roethlisberger faces a tough matchup and is coming off one of the worst performances of his career.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Has the mighty Big Ben finally fallen? (In terms of fantasy football, I mean. He was walking fine after Week 5’s game.)
2017-10-11.headline_main: Fantasy Football: Who to Start in Week 6

2017-10-11.abstract: Pioneering electronic music bands like Depeche Mode, New Order, Alphaville and Erasure have released new material. It's like the 80s all over again.
2017-10-11.snippet: Pioneering electronic music bands like Depeche Mode, New Order, Alphaville and Erasure have released new material. It's like the 80s all over again.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: “Dynasty” is back on television. “Blade Runner” is in theaters. And all your favorite synth pop bands from the 1980s, including Depeche Mode and New Order, have new albums.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Return of the ’80s! Synth-Pop Bands Stage a Middle-Aged Comeback

2017-10-11.abstract: The Supreme Court debated whether corporations may be sued for human rights abuses abroad under a cryptic 1789 law.
2017-10-11.snippet: The Supreme Court debated whether corporations may be sued for human rights abuses abroad under a cryptic 1789 law.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, which has already placed strict limits on lawsuits brought in federal court based on human rights abuses abroad, seemed open on Wednesday to barring such suits entirely when the defendants are corporations.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Justices Weigh Immunity for Corporations in Human Rights Cases Abroad

2017-10-11.abstract: The island nation was abuzz after a triumph over the United States in men’s soccer, even though it did not qualify for next year’s World Cup.
2017-10-11.snippet: The island nation was abuzz after a triumph over the United States in men’s soccer, even though it did not qualify for next year’s World Cup.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago — For Joey Richardson, a 61-year-old retired civil servant known as Porche, watching his beloved men’s soccer team crush the United States was like watching David slaying Goliath.
2017-10-11.headline_main: ‘Revenge Was Sweet’: Trinidad and Tobago Exults in Soccer Victory Over U.S.

2017-10-11.abstract: Networks authorized by the State University of New York will be able to train and approve their own teachers, a move that worries critics.
2017-10-11.snippet: Networks authorized by the State University of New York will be able to train and approve their own teachers, a move that worries critics.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: The State University of New York took a step on Wednesday that will make it easier for some charter schools to hire teachers.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Some Charter Schools Can Certify Their Own Teachers, Board Says

2017-10-11.abstract: A man fell ill after returning from Madagascar, which is struggling to contain a rash of plague cases. It is the first instance of the outbreak spreading to another country.
2017-10-11.snippet: A man fell ill after returning from Madagascar, which is struggling to contain a rash of plague cases. It is the first instance of the outbreak spreading to another country.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: The outbreak of plague in Madagascar has spread to the Seychelles, a nearby chain of islands in the Indian Ocean, the country’s health ministry said Wednesday.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Seychelles Reports a Case of Plague

2017-10-11.abstract: Some scientists think global warming may be making California’s autumn winds even drier, a “key parameter for fire risk.”
2017-10-11.snippet: Some scientists think global warming may be making California’s autumn winds even drier, a “key parameter for fire risk.”
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Powerful, hot and dry winds like those that have fanned the deadly wildfires now raging in California are a common occurrence in the state, a result of regional atmospheric patterns that develop in the fall.
2017-10-11.headline_main: California Winds Are Fueling Fires. It May Be Getting Worse.

2017-10-11.abstract: Enter the mind of a murderer with these psychological tales of evil geniuses. See the full list at Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.
2017-10-11.snippet: Enter the mind of a murderer with these psychological tales of evil geniuses. See the full list at Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Enter the mind of a murderer with these psychological tales of evil geniuses. See the full list at Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Serial Killers Are Everywhere

2017-10-11.abstract: Condoleezza Rice will lead a commission to recommend ways to fix college basketball in the wake of F.B.I. investigations into fraud in the sport.
2017-10-11.snippet: Condoleezza Rice will lead a commission to recommend ways to fix college basketball in the wake of F.B.I. investigations into fraud in the sport.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Responding to federal charges last month that depicted a corrupt black market for high school and college basketball players, the N.C.A.A. on Wednesday said that it would create a college basketball commission to investigate changes for “a system that clearly is not working.”
2017-10-11.headline_main: Amid Scandal, N.C.A.A. Forms Commission to Reform Men’s Basketball

2017-10-11.abstract: On this week’s podcast, the star of “The Handmaid’s Tale” reads Diane Daniel’s story of her spouse’s transition.
2017-10-11.snippet: On this week’s podcast, the star of “The Handmaid’s Tale” reads Diane Daniel’s story of her spouse’s transition.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: On this week’s podcast, Ann Dowd reads “My Husband Is Now My Wife,” about what changes when a spouse undergoes a gender transition, and what doesn’t.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Modern Love Podcast: Ann Dowd Reads ‘My Husband Is Now My Wife’

2017-10-11.abstract: We are sympathetic with the cause, goes the familiar and tedious argument, just don’t go overboard.
2017-10-11.snippet: We are sympathetic with the cause, goes the familiar and tedious argument, just don’t go overboard.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Not such a long time ago, in this very galaxy, civil rights protesters were lectured about finding the “right time and place” for their demonstrations. It’s all well and good to express your opinion, they were told, but in-your-face street protests are disruptive and can harden opposition.
2017-10-11.headline_main: The N.F.L.’s Workplace Dodge

2017-10-11.abstract: Collectors agreed to lift their objection to the return of an ancient marble sculpture of a bull’s head after seeing evidence that it had been stolen
2017-10-11.snippet: Collectors agreed to lift their objection to the return of an ancient marble sculpture of a bull’s head after seeing evidence that it had been stolen
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: A Colorado couple has dropped a federal lawsuit that sought to stop the Manhattan district attorney’s office from returning to the Republic of Lebanon an ancient marble bull’s head that prosecutors said had been looted during that country’s civil war.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Looted Antiquity, Once at Met Museum, to Return to Lebanon

2017-10-11.abstract: Human rights groups said the Supreme Court’s ruling was an important step forward for the rights of girls.
2017-10-11.snippet: Human rights groups said the Supreme Court’s ruling was an important step forward for the rights of girls.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s Supreme Court on Wednesday struck down a part of the country’s legal code that had permitted men to have sex with their underage wives — a decision that human rights groups said was an important step forward for the rights of girls.
2017-10-11.headline_main: India Shields Child Brides From Sex

2017-10-11.abstract: The director Angela Robinson explains how a psychologist with a three-way relationship and an interest in bondage and sadomasochism came to invent the superhero.
2017-10-11.snippet: The director Angela Robinson explains how a psychologist with a three-way relationship and an interest in bondage and sadomasochism came to invent the superhero.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: The director Angela Robinson has devoted her career to stories with strong female protagonists. Her 2005 debut, “D.E.B.S.,” was an action-adventure film dominated by women. Her next feature, “Herbie Fully Loaded,” put Lindsay Lohan in the driver’s seat of that Disney franchise. Now her focus is on one of the strongest female characters in pop culture, Wonder Woman. Ms. Robinson’s biopic, “Professor Marston and the Wonder Women,” opening Friday, reveals the surprising back story of the superhero (and summer box-office star).
2017-10-11.headline_main: Wonder Woman’s Surprising Back Story Has a Film of Its Own

2017-10-11.abstract: The New York Times asked women whether they have been afraid to speak up after being harassed.
2017-10-11.snippet: The New York Times asked women whether they have been afraid to speak up after being harassed.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Last week, after a New York Times investigation found a hidden history of sexual harassment allegations against the Hollywood film producer Harvey Weinstein, The Times asked women to share their own experiences with power imbalance in the workplace and whether they have ever been afraid to speak up.
2017-10-11.headline_main: ‘I Was Blacklisted From Employment’: Speaking Up in the Workplace

2017-10-11.abstract: An Alison Lou ear-piercing party, a Nicholas Kirkwood customization event, Iris Apfel bangles to buy, and more.
2017-10-11.snippet: An Alison Lou ear-piercing party, a Nicholas Kirkwood customization event, Iris Apfel bangles to buy, and more.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: The Arrivals, an outerwear label, will open a holiday pop-up on Thursday. There you’ll find smart options to wrap up warmly, like a modular bomber jacket with a removable lamb shearling collar ($395). At 42 Crosby Street.
2017-10-11.headline_main: A Week of Openings, Pop-ups and Other Shopping Events

2017-10-11.abstract: Weaker carriers have fallen by the wayside amid fierce competition, while others have been hit by bad luck. The result: thousands of canceled flights.
2017-10-11.snippet: Weaker carriers have fallen by the wayside amid fierce competition, while others have been hit by bad luck. The result: thousands of canceled flights.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Adela Vyhnakova arrived at Dublin Airport this month hoping that nothing else would go wrong with her trip to the Spanish island of Gran Canaria.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Passengers Suffer as Crowded Field Puts Pressure on Europe’s Airlines

2017-10-11.abstract: One student was charged with negligent homicide and nine current or former students were charged with hazing after a fraternity pledge died of alcohol poisoning.
2017-10-11.snippet: One student was charged with negligent homicide and nine current or former students were charged with hazing after a fraternity pledge died of alcohol poisoning.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Ten current or former students at Louisiana State University were arrested Wednesday in connection with the death last month of an 18-year-old freshman who became severely intoxicated during a fraternity hazing ordeal, the latest in a series of student deaths following such rituals.
2017-10-11.headline_main: 10 Arrested in Death of L.S.U. Student After Fraternity Drinking Ritual

2017-10-11.abstract: Maria’s winds ripped through the only tropical rain forest in the United States forest system, decimating much of its flora and fauna.
2017-10-11.snippet: Maria’s winds ripped through the only tropical rain forest in the United States forest system, decimating much of its flora and fauna.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: LUQUILLO, P.R. — When you looked up, you could once see nothing but the lush, emerald canopy of tabonuco and sierra palm trees covering El Yunque National Forest.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Another Victim of Hurricane Maria: Puerto Rico’s Treasured Rainforest

2017-10-11.abstract: New Yorkers training for the big race, beset with injuries big and small, flock to physical therapists in the weeks leading up to the event.
2017-10-11.snippet: New Yorkers training for the big race, beset with injuries big and small, flock to physical therapists in the weeks leading up to the event.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: On a recent autumn afternoon in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, New Yorkers packed into a sunny loft filled with reduced-gravity treadmills and gait-analysis software. Some lay prostrate, guiding themselves over foam rollers, while others had their legs wrapped in compression bands or bulky massage boots. There were cryotherapy chambers and a Ping-Pong table. The Ed Sheeran song “Shape of You” filled the room.
2017-10-11.headline_main: It’s Marathon Season, and Physical Therapists Are Busy

2017-10-11.abstract: A man arrested in Arkansas faces a charge of malicious wounding in the August beating of DeAndre Harris, 20, at a rally of white nationalists in August.
2017-10-11.snippet: A man arrested in Arkansas faces a charge of malicious wounding in the August beating of DeAndre Harris, 20, at a rally of white nationalists in August.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: A third man has been arrested in the beating of a black man at a rally of white nationalists in Charlottesville, Va., in August, the authorities said on Wednesday.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Third Man Arrested in Beating of Black Man at Charlottesville Rally

2017-10-11.abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
2017-10-11.snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
2017-10-11.headline_main: California, Harvey Weinstein, Boy Scouts: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing

2017-10-11.abstract: In an area called “Silicon Slopes,” at least five start-ups are valued at more than $1 billion, a sign that Utah has become a growing force for tech incubation.
2017-10-11.snippet: In an area called “Silicon Slopes,” at least five start-ups are valued at more than $1 billion, a sign that Utah has become a growing force for tech incubation.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: When Josh James traveled to the Bay Area in 2000, seeking funding for a web analytics company he had founded, he spoke at length with a venture capitalist about his plans for growth. The conversation was going well, Mr. James recently recalled, until the investor asked where he was based. “As soon as I told him I was from Utah, he literally, without saying a word, turned around and walked away.”
2017-10-11.headline_main: As ‘Unicorns’ Emerge, Utah Makes a Case for Tech Entrepreneurs

2017-10-11.abstract: The family of S.I. Newhouse Jr. has chosen Tobias Meyer to help determine how to handle Mr. Newhouse’s formidable trove of art.
2017-10-11.snippet: The family of S.I. Newhouse Jr. has chosen Tobias Meyer to help determine how to handle Mr. Newhouse’s formidable trove of art.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: The art world has long wondered what would become of S.I. Newhouse Jr.’s formidable art collection after his death, since the media mogul had been ill for some time.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Former Sotheby’s Auctioneer to Advise on Newhouse Art Collection

2017-10-11.abstract: Ruth Asawa’s metal sculptures, Anne Imhof and Eliza Douglas’s collaborations, Sally Saul’s ceramics and a São Paulo gallery’s New York outpost.
2017-10-11.snippet: Ruth Asawa’s metal sculptures, Anne Imhof and Eliza Douglas’s collaborations, Sally Saul’s ceramics and a São Paulo gallery’s New York outpost.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Through Oct. 21. David Zwirner, 537 West 20th Street, Manhattan; davidzwirner.com.
2017-10-11.headline_main: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week

2017-10-11.abstract: Northern California fires forced more than 20,000 people to leave their homes. When some Santa Rosa residents went back to check on their houses, there was nothing left.
2017-10-11.snippet: Northern California fires forced more than 20,000 people to leave their homes. When some Santa Rosa residents went back to check on their houses, there was nothing left.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Northern California fires forced more than 20,000 people to leave their homes. When some Santa Rosa residents went back to check on their houses, there was nothing left.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Californians Return to Fire-Ravaged Homes: ‘Everything Is Just Gone’

2017-10-11.abstract: In connection with his new show, “Paradise Lost,” the artist debuts a selection of images.
2017-10-11.snippet: In connection with his new show, “Paradise Lost,” the artist debuts a selection of images.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: In connection with his new show, “Paradise Lost,” the artist debuts a selection of images.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Chris Ofili’s Images of Trinidad

2017-10-11.abstract: In a series of images exclusive to T, the British artist — whose new show is on view at David Zwirner now — captures scenes on the island.
2017-10-11.snippet: In a series of images exclusive to T, the British artist — whose new show is on view at David Zwirner now — captures scenes on the island.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Chris Ofili was the subject of a solo show at the National Gallery in London called “Weaving Magic,” where he debuted an expansive, hand-woven tapestry. And last month, he opened another exhibition, titled “Paradise Lost,” at David Zwirner in New York, which showcases four oil-and-charcoal paintings and one sculpture: a human puppet, suspended in a bird cage crafted out of wood and gold-plated wire.
2017-10-11.headline_main: The Artist Chris Ofili Captures Trinidad, in Pictures

2017-10-11.abstract: When Fox paid $400 million for the rights to broadcast the 2018 and 2022 World Cups, it certainly hoped the United States would qualify.
2017-10-11.snippet: When Fox paid $400 million for the rights to broadcast the 2018 and 2022 World Cups, it certainly hoped the United States would qualify.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: The United States might not be good enough to win soccer’s World Cup, but as long as it shows up at the quadrennial tournament the domestic audience is sure to swell with casual fans rooting for an upset.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Fox and Others Will Feel Pain of U.S. Absence at World Cup

2017-10-11.abstract: A group of renegade Republicans, who made Nancy Pelosi into a successful boogeyman for their base, are now trying the same tactic with one of their own: Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader.
2017-10-11.snippet: A group of renegade Republicans, who made Nancy Pelosi into a successful boogeyman for their base, are now trying the same tactic with one of their own: Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Republicans trying to rally their base, no political villain has been more effective than Representative Nancy Pelosi, the longtime Democratic leader. In campaign after campaign, they made her the symbol of the Washington they claimed to be running against.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Conservatives Want to Make Mitch McConnell the Symbol of a Toxic Washington

2017-10-11.abstract: With Tropical Storm Ophelia’s transition to Hurricane Ophelia, 2017 became the first year since 1893 in which 10 Atlantic storms in a row reached hurricane strength.
2017-10-11.snippet: With Tropical Storm Ophelia’s transition to Hurricane Ophelia, 2017 became the first year since 1893 in which 10 Atlantic storms in a row reached hurricane strength.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: With Tropical Storm Ophelia’s transition to Hurricane Ophelia on Wednesday, 2017 became the first year in more than a century — and only the fourth on record — in which 10 Atlantic storms in a row reached hurricane strength.
2017-10-11.headline_main: 10 Hurricanes in 10 Weeks: With Ophelia, a 124-Year-Old Record is Matched

2017-10-11.abstract: The man, who was assigned to the parish for nearly 25 years, is accused of sexually abusing the girls when they were 5 to 16 years old, between 1972 and 1994.
2017-10-11.snippet: The man, who was assigned to the parish for nearly 25 years, is accused of sexually abusing the girls when they were 5 to 16 years old, between 1972 and 1994.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: A former teacher at a Catholic school in Queens who said she had reported the sexual abuse of seven female students by a priest in 1991 now claims that the Diocese of Brooklyn covered it up for more than a decade, allowing more girls to be abused.
2017-10-11.headline_main: 23 Women Accuse Former Queens Priest of Abusing Them as Children

2017-10-11.abstract: The statements from House Intelligence Committee leaders were the first indication that the ads would be made public.
2017-10-11.snippet: The statements from House Intelligence Committee leaders were the first indication that the ads would be made public.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Leaders of the House Intelligence Committee said on Wednesday that they planned to make public the thousands of Facebook ads linked to Russia that appeared during the 2016 presidential election campaign, the first indication that the ads would be released.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Lawmakers Say They Plan to Release Facebook Ads Linked to Russia

2017-10-11.abstract: President Trump is expected to issue an order on Thursday to allow the sale of health insurance plans that are exempt from some Affordable Care Act rules.
2017-10-11.snippet: President Trump is expected to issue an order on Thursday to allow the sale of health insurance plans that are exempt from some Affordable Care Act rules.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, after failing  to repeal the Affordable Care Act in Congress, will act on his own to relax health care standards on small businesses that band together to buy health insurance and may take steps to allow the sale of other health plans that skirt the health law’s requirements.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Foiled in Congress, Trump Moves on His Own to Undermine Obamacare

2017-10-11.abstract: The opposition leader, Raila Odinga, has said he would not take part in the new election, scheduled for Oct. 26, because he did not believe it would be fair.
2017-10-11.snippet: The opposition leader, Raila Odinga, has said he would not take part in the new election, scheduled for Oct. 26, because he did not believe it would be fair.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenya’s electoral commission said Wednesday that it would go ahead with a repeat of the recent presidential election, even though one of the main candidates has said he is withdrawing from the race because he does not believe it would be free and fair.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Kenyan Election Officials Open New Vote to All Original Candidates

2017-10-11.abstract: A high-tech film studio near Syracuse came with the promise of jobs, which failed to materialize along with rent payments, according to a court complaint.
2017-10-11.snippet: A high-tech film studio near Syracuse came with the promise of jobs, which failed to materialize along with rent payments, according to a court complaint.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a $15 million investment to build a film studio hub in DeWitt, N.Y., in 2014, state officials vowed the complex would bring 350 high-tech film jobs of the sort more often seen in Hollywood to this town in Central New York.
2017-10-11.headline_main: A State-Boosted Film Studio Hub Faces Possible Eviction

2017-10-11.abstract: “It feels like we’ve been left to ourselves,” my friend said to me.
2017-10-11.snippet: “It feels like we’ve been left to ourselves,” my friend said to me.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: NAZARETH, V.I. — The day after Hurricane Maria finally subsided, I looked up at the ceiling and exhaled. “Thank you,” I whispered, relieved to still be alive.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Has America Forgotten the Virgin Islands?

2017-10-11.abstract: Reporting on technology has changed this year — what once felt like a world of boundless possibility now comes freighted with worry.
2017-10-11.snippet: Reporting on technology has changed this year — what once felt like a world of boundless possibility now comes freighted with worry.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: It’s gadget season in the tech world. Think of it like New York Fashion Week, untucked white-man edition.
2017-10-11.headline_main: Why Tech Is Starting to Make Me Uneasy

2017-10-11.abstract: On the front lines, exhausted crews are stretched to their limits as they try to slow wildfires that have grown so big, so fast.
2017-10-11.snippet: On the front lines, exhausted crews are stretched to their limits as they try to slow wildfires that have grown so big, so fast.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: GLEN ELLEN, Calif. — Hundreds of sleep-deprived, stubble-faced firefighters, their yellow coats layered with soot, assembled here Wednesday to hear their commanders say what they already knew: The fires that have devastated California’s wine country were still spreading, nowhere near containment, and the crews battling the blazes were stretched to their limits.
2017-10-11.headline_main: California Wildfires Death Toll Rises to 29 as Vast Region Is Scorched

2017-10-11.abstract: Ronan Farrow was an NBC contributor when he began reporting on claims that Mr. Weinstein had mistreated women. The article ended up being published by The New Yorker.
2017-10-11.snippet: Ronan Farrow was an NBC contributor when he began reporting on claims that Mr. Weinstein had mistreated women. The article ended up being published by The New Yorker.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: When Ronan Farrow made a guest appearance on MSNBC’s “The Rachel Maddow Show” on Tuesday night, he tried to make it clear that he was the reporter, not the story.

2017-10-11.abstract: Australians describe their own experiences with the country’s “rules over risk” mentality, asking if their country is too rigid, or too compliant.

2017-10-11.abstract: The outdoor jail in Arizona attracted national attention for the tactics of the former sheriff, who was convicted of ignoring an order to stop racially profiling and later pardoned.
2017-10-11.snippet: The outdoor jail in Arizona attracted national attention for the tactics of the former sheriff, who was convicted of ignoring an order to stop racially profiling and later pardoned.
2017-10-11.lead_paragraph: After 24 years in operation, Tent City, an outdoor Arizona jail that served as an emblem of former Sheriff Joe Arpaio’s “tough on crime” stance, has been closed. The final 370 or so inmates were transferred to another detention facility, and the area was officially shut down on Saturday.

It was a remarkable sight, for Strasburg had been sick in recent days and was not supposed to pitch, even with his team on the brink of elimination.

2017-10-12.abstract: Can “Mr. Robot” get out of its own head and recapture the fun that made its first season so intoxicating? Wednesday’s premiere suggests that it has.
2017-10-12.snippet: Can “Mr. Robot” get out of its own head and recapture the fun that made its first season so intoxicating? Wednesday’s premiere suggests that it has.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: “Mr. Robot” debuted in 2015 as a captivating and uncanny reflection of not just our fractious times — all those eerie parallels with real-world events — but also of the isolating effects of technology billed and sold as a means of connection. The story was to our world as Mr. Robot was to Elliot: A darker, (somewhat) angrier version, with a mysterious agenda born of deep pain.
2017-10-12.headline_main: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 3 Premiere: A Whole New World

2017-10-12.abstract: The creator of the USA techno-thriller discusses the new season, which began on Wednesday.
2017-10-12.snippet: The creator of the USA techno-thriller discusses the new season, which began on Wednesday.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: “Mr. Robot” began as a story about a troubled programmer but steadily expanded to encompass underground revolutionaries, global power brokers and a hack that disrupted the entire world. The USA techno-thriller returned for its third season Wednesday night with even broader horizons, as key characters like Whiterose (B. D. Wong) and Angela Moss (Portia Doubleday) seemed to envision alternate universes, while the tormented hero, Elliot (Rami Malek), resumed his baroque existential struggles. The episode found him recuperating from last season’s culminating gunshot and pondering ways to counteract his Mr. Robot alter ego, specifically his world-shattering acts of cyberterrorism.
2017-10-12.headline_main: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 3 Premiere: Sam Esmail on Parallel Universes and President Trump

2017-10-12.abstract: We asked people to share how the wildfires affected them. Here are some of their stories.

2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Fashion has an addiction problem. I am not talking about illicit substances here, though the industry’s past issues with those have been well documented. Rather, I am talking about illicit … well, talk. Gossip. It seems unable to stop, and it is getting worse. In Paris last week there was more leaking going on in the maisons of Avenue Montaigne than in the Trump White House.

2017-10-12.snippet: Unlike an elopement, a microwedding retains some of the structure of a traditional wedding, except on a smaller scale.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: My dream wedding was a bare-bones affair. After four years of dating, my fiancé, Mike, and I exchanged vows in a courtroom 14 floors above his office last April. His boss, a prominent judge, officiated. Only our immediate families and my two best friends were in attendance. I didn’t even carry a bouquet. When the 10-minute ceremony was over, we snapped a few photos before we dined at a farm-to-table restaurant across the street.
2017-10-12.headline_main: What to Know About Having a Microwedding

2017-10-12.abstract: The island doesn’t need threats. It needs experts who know how to get essential supplies to disaster zones.
2017-10-12.snippet: The island doesn’t need threats. It needs experts who know how to get essential supplies to disaster zones.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: “You can’t get sick now” in Puerto Rico, Lisandra Figueroa told The New York Times after her father died last week when breakdowns in supplies and transportation deprived him of bottled oxygen. Three weeks after Hurricane Maria devastated the island, scarce medical supplies, equipment and power mean illnesses easily treated under normal conditions now can be a death sentence in remote areas. Puerto Ricans who suffered injuries in the storm, who contracted infections from polluted floodwaters or drinking water, or who have chronic conditions requiring continuous care are not receiving help, and are dying.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Getting Help Where It’s Needed in Puerto Rico

2017-10-12.abstract: How can third-party sellers offer “new” books at prices below even the Amazon discount?
2017-10-12.snippet: How can third-party sellers offer “new” books at prices below even the Amazon discount?
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: LAST March, Amazon quietly changed the way it sells books. An obscure and seemingly harmless modification to its website has opened the door for some third-party sellers to deceive Amazon’s customers by selling books as “new” that may not come straight from a publisher or its wholesaler, thus depriving authors of royalties they should have earned from the sale of a new book.
2017-10-12.headline_main: From Amazon, a Change That Hurts Authors

2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Though Monika Bulaj grew up in Communist Poland, she was nonetheless a devoutly Catholic child who studied mystics and dreamed of a life as a cloistered nun. 2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, at Easter dinner with my in-laws, I noticed my husband’s grandmother dipping pieces of yellow cake into her glass of soda. She’s a woman of nearly 90 with a preternatural grip for hugs and pinching cheeks but, in this, she was gentle: letting each bite soak into her orange Crush, allowing it to achieve full saturation before popping it in her mouth.

2017-10-12.abstract: After 17 years, the author of the trilogy “His Dark Materials” carries on the story of one of literature’s most indelible heroines.
2017-10-12.snippet: After 17 years, the author of the trilogy “His Dark Materials” carries on the story of one of literature’s most indelible heroines.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: On one of my first meetings with Philip Pullman, he led me to the crenelated tower of Exeter College, in Oxford, and pointed out the room he lived in as a student. More than 50 feet up from the ground was a tiny attic window. To visit friends living in rooms on the adjacent staircase — accessible only at ground level — Pullman, a tall, sturdy man with a head like a boulder, would clamber out his window, shimmy along a gutter and propel himself through a window into a bathroom. From where we were standing, the feat looked unlikely, and unwise. Pullman was self-deprecating. “It was less precarious than it seems because it’s actually quite a large gutter, and it’s quite deep,” he said. “And I was drunk. So.”
2017-10-12.headline_main: Philip Pullman Returns to His Fantasy World

2017-10-12.abstract: The restaurant favorite is just as easy to make at home.
2017-10-12.snippet: The restaurant favorite is just as easy to make at home.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: With some frequency these days, you’ll hear talk of cooking “with love” — that supposed secret ingredient, the intangible something extra that makes a chef’s food so good. I am sure that is accurate for some, but I imagine that what is identified as love is probably thoroughness and follow-through and taking the time that work-done-properly takes. What you unfortunately don’t get to hear very often (unless you work in kitchens) is how sharp and droll and cynical and pragmatic chefs can be too. I’m not saying you can taste it in the food, but every kitchen everywhere has a charming and agreeable dose of jadedness — a vaguely begrudging eye roll expressed most commonly when it comes to menu-planning time in the observation “You could throw your grandmother on the grill with goat cheese and artichokes and sell a thousand plates a night.”
2017-10-12.headline_main: Cooking Duck Not With Love but With Pleasure

2017-10-12.abstract: Proposed mines near the Boundary Waters have become the latest front in the fight over who gets to profit from America’s natural resources.
2017-10-12.snippet: Proposed mines near the Boundary Waters have become the latest front in the fight over who gets to profit from America’s natural resources.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Minnesota is home to some of the world’s most ancient rocks, as old as 3.5 billion years. Earth has been around for only 4.5 billion years. About 2.7 billion years ago, basalt lava flowed underwater near what’s now the state’s border with Canada; the lava hardened, and the creep of geologic time turned it into a bedrock of greenstone and granite. On top of it, a layer of sedimentary rock rich in iron ore formed nearly two billion years ago, when the region was ocean floor. Then a billion years ago, Earth’s crust cracked open, producing a 50-mile-wide fissure stretching from Lake Superior to Kansas. For the next 100 million years, lava bubbled up into what geologists call the Midcontinent Rift, forming a mineral deposit filled with copper and nickel. Settlers first made their way to the area in 1865 in a fruitless search for gold. What they did find was iron ore, and lots of it. Rails were laid for iron-ore transport, and the town of Ely was founded a few years later, in 1888.
2017-10-12.headline_main: In Northern Minnesota, Two Economies Square Off: Mining vs. Wilderness

2017-10-12.snippet: Cracking up may be a better option than breaking down, or so three recent books by young people with cancer suggest.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: During periods of hardship, laughter can lighten the load. Cracking up may be a better option than breaking down, or so the recent publications of three young adults with cancer suggest. Somewhat discomfiting, the jests of these authors serve as an antidote and alternative to the despairing negativity or fake positivity that plagues patients like me. Their punch lines zing with pleasure that offsets the pain of their edgy insights.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Cancer Humor

2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: VADUZ, Liechtenstein — Balloons still bobbed on the stairway, more than two weeks after the 105th birthday celebration for Baron Eduard von Falz-Fein. He attributed his longevity to the succor of honey and Ovaltine. Still, his body had become a husk, but not his mind. It whirred and clicked like the monitor at his bedside.
2017-10-12.headline_main: A Seat Near Hitler, and Other Olympic Tales From the Baron, 105

2017-10-12.abstract: Ms. Sandberg visited Washington, acting as the tech giant’s chief ambassador while trying to contain a spiraling public relations crisis.
2017-10-12.snippet: Ms. Sandberg visited Washington, acting as the tech giant’s chief ambassador while trying to contain a spiraling public relations crisis.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, Facebook has been trying to counter criticism about its influence on the 2016 presidential election. The company has hired three crisis communications firms and has bought digital and newspaper ads. Mark Zuckerberg, its chief executive, has posted live video to the social network to explain how much he cared about election integrity.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Sheryl Sandberg Blitzes Washington in P.R. Push for Facebook

2017-10-12.abstract: Shadow boxing with left-wing campus activists isn’t courageous. Challenging the ideas of his fans would be.
2017-10-12.snippet: Shadow boxing with left-wing campus activists isn’t courageous. Challenging the ideas of his fans would be.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Ben Shapiro, the conservative writer, prides himself on speaking bold truths to liberal power. His shtick goes something like this: Set up a speech in a progressive bastion, ideally a college campus full of coastal elites who have never left their bubble. Spar with snowflakes who are offended by something he says about race or gender and perhaps even believe he never should have been invited in the first place. Post the exchange on the internet and use it as proof that the cultural consensus is stacked dramatically against conservatives. As Mr. Shapiro has put it: “The left has run out of aggressors to target; instead, they’ve become the aggressors, self-righteous morality police dedicated to wiping out dissenting thought.”
2017-10-12.headline_main: The Hollow Bravery of Ben Shapiro

2017-10-12.abstract: The Israeli government’s hard-line tactics have found their way to the United States. Can the Constitution stop them?
2017-10-12.snippet: The Israeli government’s hard-line tactics have found their way to the United States. Can the Constitution stop them?
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: For decades, I’ve supported activists working toward democracy and equality in Israel. But in the past eight years under Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, that fight has become much more difficult. Bills we once thought the Knesset would never allow to be even introduced are now the law of the land. This crackdown has included the entrenchment of Israel’s occupation of Palestinian territories, but also government support for McCarthy-like witch hunts of undesirable progressive activists — many of which have targeted the New Israel Fund, the organization I lead, and the progressive Israeli nonprofits we fund.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Congress’s Un-American, Bad-for-Israel Agenda

2017-10-12.abstract: The Chiefs look to remain perfect, while the Jaguars hope to quit their Jekyll and Hyde routine. Here are our picks against the spread.
2017-10-12.snippet: The Chiefs look to remain perfect, while the Jaguars hope to quit their Jekyll and Hyde routine. Here are our picks against the spread.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: The pecking order in the N.F.L. is starting to emerge. The Chiefs, Packers and Panthers are right at the top, with the Eagles, Lions, Patriots and Falcons looming just behind them. Stuck somewhere between “best team in the N.F.L.” and “totally incompetent” are the Jacksonville Jaguars. Their Jekyll and Hyde season has gone W-L-W-L-W, and they managed the nearly impossible feat of losing to the Jets in Week 4 and then completely demoralizing the Steelers in Week 5. Their pendulum could continue to swing, but maybe, just maybe, they can win a second game in a row. Here are our picks against the spread.
2017-10-12.headline_main: N.F.L. Week 6 Picks: Chiefs Over Steelers; Packers Over Vikings

2017-10-12.abstract: Poor play derailed the team after it led the Yankees in the division series, two games to none, and after a regular season featuring 102 wins and a 22-game win streak.
2017-10-12.snippet: Poor play derailed the team after it led the Yankees in the division series, two games to none, and after a regular season featuring 102 wins and a 22-game win streak.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When this latest sad volume of Cleveland Indians history is written, bound and placed on a shelf alongside all the others, the 2017 team will be remembered for two notable streaks: the 22 consecutive games it won in August and September, and the three in a row it lost in October.
2017-10-12.headline_main: What Happened to the Cleveland Indians?

2017-10-12.abstract: And: the friend who won’t wash his hands after using the bathroom; sharing one’s rape story with a boyfriend; the old “throw out some dates” gambit.
2017-10-12.snippet: And: the friend who won’t wash his hands after using the bathroom; sharing one’s rape story with a boyfriend; the old “throw out some dates” gambit.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: My Uncle Eddy died unexpectedly. He never married and had no children, but he was very close to my brother and his wife. Eddy spent every occasion with them. He wrote a will leaving them everything but never signed it. Under state law, our lawyer says, Eddy’s property will be split among his three siblings, none of whom spoke to him. Eddy was tough. My brother and his wife were the only ones who could take his tirades. But they loved him. One of Eddy’s siblings will honor the unsigned will; the others want their money. Help our divided family!
2017-10-12.headline_main: What Happens When a Will is Unsigned? (It’s Not Fun)

2017-10-12.abstract: A biopic about the rise of a Native American performer who overcame discriminatory laws to perform on Broadway and in the White House.
2017-10-12.snippet: A biopic about the rise of a Native American performer who overcame discriminatory laws to perform on Broadway and in the White House.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Born in 1895, the Chickasaw performer Te Ata came of age at a time when the United States prohibited public displays of Native American culture. Yet despite laws dictating that her indigenous performances remain private, Te Ata eventually acted and danced on Broadway and for President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s White House. She became an advocate, through her own artistic excellence, for the inherent dignity that the federal government denied American Indians — fittingly, her stage name means “bearer of the morning.” Te Ata’s life story is now the subject of Nathan Frankowski’s film “Te Ata,” which goes for the sweep of an epic despite a tight budget.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Review: ‘Te Ata’ Shares a Heroic Story of a Chickasaw Ambassador

2017-10-12.abstract: New Yorkers were exposed to yellow fever and cholera because of tainted local sources—and antics by Aaron Burr—until the Croton Aqueduct opened in 1842.

2017-10-12.abstract: Reginald Hudlin’s movie about the crusading lawyer and Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall smartly keeps the focus tight.
2017-10-12.snippet: Reginald Hudlin’s movie about the crusading lawyer and Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall smartly keeps the focus tight.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Some biopics go for sweeping and exhaustive, trying to cram an entire life into a tidy two hours or so. “Marshall” smartly opts for modest. With economy, a bit of gauzy nostalgia and likable performances, it revisits an early episode from the life of Thurgood Marshall, the civil rights lawyer who became the first African-American to hold a seat on the Supreme Court. From the 1940s to the early ’60s, he argued 32 cases before the court, winning most. “Sometimes history takes things into its own hands,” Marshall once said, but he also regularly gave history a shove.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Review: In ‘Marshall,’ a Legal Pioneer Gives History a Shove

2017-10-12.abstract: Mr. La Selva’s loftily named troupe, though intended as a people’s opera company, brought masterworks to Carnegie Hall as well as Central Park.

2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Vincent La Selva, who exuberantly weathered thunderstorms, flimsy sets, crackling audio, frayed costumes and sometimes inexpert performers so that his spare but enormously popular company, the New York Grand Opera, might live up to its lofty name, died on Monday in Parma, Ohio. He was 88.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Vincent La Selva, Dauntless Founder of New York Grand Opera, Dies at 88

2017-10-12.abstract: Ai Weiwei has endured frequent gripes that his activism has got the better of his art. That gripe is unfounded.
2017-10-12.snippet: Ai Weiwei has endured frequent gripes that his activism has got the better of his art. That gripe is unfounded.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Ai Weiwei lives his life in public: blogging his anger at the Chinese government, transforming his detention into harrowing dioramas, and now Instagramming up a storm from his exile in Berlin. Over the last two years, the world’s most famous artist-activist has been traveling to refugee camps from Greece to Iraq and Gaza to Myanmar, documenting the displacement of millions and the borders they are desperate to cross. Others might have stayed behind the camera. Mr. Ai, now a refugee himself, puts himself right in front.
2017-10-12.headline_main: From China’s Artist-Activist, a Citywide Great Wall

2017-10-12.abstract: In “Professor Marston and the Wonder Women,” the writer-director Angela Robinson tells a knotty story with wit, sympathy and economy.
2017-10-12.snippet: In “Professor Marston and the Wonder Women,” the writer-director Angela Robinson tells a knotty story with wit, sympathy and economy.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Suffering Sappho, Batman, you’re such a square! That’s especially true when you consider the real origin of Wonder Woman, the warrior with the indestructible bracelets and slightly kinky magic lasso who burst into comics in 1941. As it happens, there was more kink to her story than suggested by that golden lasso, which she uses to force her captives to tell the truth and looks like something from a bondage emporium. “On Paradise Island where we play many binding games,” she says in an early comic while roping another woman, “this is considered the safest method of tying a girl’s arms!”
2017-10-12.headline_main: Review: ‘Professor Marston,’ With Kinks! Pleasures! Female Power!

2017-10-12.snippet: A documentary from an artist who wants to take viewers beyond the headlines and the images on the nightly news.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: There are moments in “Human Flow,” a bracing, often strangely beautiful movie by the artist Ai Weiwei, when it can be hard to see the individuals who make up the roiling, surging rivers onscreen. This difficulty in isolating specific people — really seeing them as sovereign beings rather than as an undifferentiated mass — is crucial to the meaning of the documentary, which charts the global refugee and migrant crisis. Shot over the course of one year in 23 countries, the movie tracks the here and there of people whose relentless ebbing and flowing make startlingly visible what news headlines repeatedly suggest: that ours is an age of ceaseless churn with no calm in sight.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Review: Ai Weiwei’s ‘Human Flow’ Tracks the Global Migrant Crisis

2017-10-12.abstract: A bright and popular 15-year-old Bronx boy was stabbed last month in one of the places he loved most — school.
2017-10-12.snippet: A bright and popular 15-year-old Bronx boy was stabbed last month in one of the places he loved most — school.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: The pint-size youngster with an oversized backpack stood on the corner of Mapes Avenue several feet from home, and for a moment contemplated crossing the street. He knew he wasn’t supposed to leave home alone, but he wanted to go to school just like his older brother though he was not old enough, his mother recounted.
2017-10-12.headline_main: ‘Nothing Will Ever be the Same’: A Murdered Teen’s Mother Speaks

2017-10-12.abstract: Her trip was organized by Liberty Counsel, a conservative research group that represented her when she was held in 2015 for contempt of court.
2017-10-12.snippet: Her trip was organized by Liberty Counsel, a conservative research group that represented her when she was held in 2015 for contempt of court.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: The Kentucky official who was jailed in 2015 for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples has been advocating against gay marriage this week thousands of miles from home — in Romania, where a movement to outlaw such unions has gained momentum.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Kim Davis, Once Jailed in America, Campaigns Against Gay Marriage in Romania

2017-10-12.abstract: A study by the city’s Independent Budget Office estimated weekday subway delays resulted in $307 million of lost work time in a 12-month period.
2017-10-12.snippet: A study by the city’s Independent Budget Office estimated weekday subway delays resulted in $307 million of lost work time in a 12-month period.

2017-10-12.headline_main: Subway Delays Cost New Yorkers Millions Annually, Report Finds

2017-10-12.abstract: Book a private room for a meal, ask the kitchen to prepare family recipes and plan a special excursion.
2017-10-12.snippet: Book a private room for a meal, ask the kitchen to prepare family recipes and plan a special excursion.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: If you’re traveling over a holiday like Thanksgiving, Christmas or Hanukkah, don’t forget to celebrate it with style, says Rebecca Gardner, an event designer in Savannah, Ga., who is creating a holiday boutique, Sugarplum Pop-Up, in November and December at the St. Regis New York. “Holidays are a time to connect with those closest to you, and when you’re on a trip, there can be a tendency to lose sight of the specialness of the occasion,” she said.
2017-10-12.headline_main: How to Celebrate Holidays on the Road

2017-10-12.abstract: An Italian pet owner got two days of paid leave to care for her ailing English setter. Animal rights groups say it could be a precedent.
2017-10-12.snippet: An Italian pet owner got two days of paid leave to care for her ailing English setter. Animal rights groups say it could be a precedent.

2017-10-12.headline_main: Paid Leave When Your Dog Is Sick? Sì, Italian Employer Says

2017-10-12.abstract: Mr. Schiller, often teamed with Bob Weiskopf, had to his credit numerous episodes of “I Love Lucy,” “Maude” and “All in the Family,” among others.
2017-10-12.snippet: Mr. Schiller, often teamed with Bob Weiskopf, had to his credit numerous episodes of “I Love Lucy,” “Maude” and “All in the Family,” among others.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Bob Schiller, a longtime television writer who had a hand in putting Lucy in a vat of grapes, getting Maude memorably slapped and pitting Edith Bunker against a rapist, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 98.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Bob Schiller, Writer on Beloved TV Comedies, Dies at 98

2017-10-12.abstract: The organization is framing a cynical business strategy as a progressive step forward. Don’t fall for it.
2017-10-12.snippet: The organization is framing a cynical business strategy as a progressive step forward. Don’t fall for it.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: The news arrived on Oct. 11, a day — as Facebook reminded us — designated as the International Day of the Girl. On the surface, it even seemed like it might be a progressive change: The Boy Scouts of America announced that it would allow girls to participate in Cub Scouts and to eventually earn Eagle Scout rank.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Girls, Don’t Become Boy Scouts

2017-10-12.abstract: The night before their release was announced, President Trump teased the pending freedom of an American woman and her family who were held hostage for five years.
2017-10-12.snippet: The night before their release was announced, President Trump teased the pending freedom of an American woman and her family who were held hostage for five years.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He was talking taxes with truckers on Wednesday evening when President Trump suddenly diverged into a curious tangent. He had been given “some very, very important news” that “you’ll probably be hearing about” in the next few days. What it was, he did not say.
2017-10-12.headline_main: In Speech to Truckers, Trump Hinted at Hostage Release

2017-10-12.abstract: It is a form of torture, and it sent inmates out of prison worse than when they arrived.
2017-10-12.snippet: It is a form of torture, and it sent inmates out of prison worse than when they arrived.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — For years, the Colorado corrections system had a ready answer for inmates it wanted to punish. For almost any reason — smuggling drugs, talking back to a corrections officer, assaulting another prisoner — it would send an inmate to a cell the size of a parking spot. The inmate would stay there, alone, at least 22 hours a day, for two and a half years on average, but sometimes for decades. This is called administrative segregation, and shortly after I became Colorado’s head of corrections in 2013, I began to ask why we were doing it.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Why We Ended Long-Term Solitary Confinement in Colorado

2017-10-12.abstract: The relief package is the second installment of aid passed by lawmakers to respond to this year’s hurricanes, and much more money will still be needed.
2017-10-12.snippet: The relief package is the second installment of aid passed by lawmakers to respond to this year’s hurricanes, and much more money will still be needed.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House, dismissing concern for the rising cost, approved a $36.5 billion aid package on Thursday that would provide hurricane and wildfire relief funding while bailing out the financially troubled National Flood Insurance Program.
2017-10-12.headline_main: House Approves $36.5 Billion Hurricane and Wildfire Aid Package

2017-10-12.abstract: Following reports on the allegations of sexual harassment and assault against Harvey Weinstein, the Weinstein Company’s publishing imprint is shut down
2017-10-12.snippet: Following reports on the allegations of sexual harassment and assault against Harvey Weinstein, the Weinstein Company’s publishing imprint is shut down
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: The fallout from the sexual harassment and assault allegations against producer Harvey Weinstein continued to spread throughout the entertainment industry on Thursday, with Hachette Book Group announcing that they are shutting down the Weinstein Company’s publishing imprint, Weinstein Books.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Weinstein Books Is Shuttered by Hachette Book Group

2017-10-12.abstract: Men have long complained about how condoms fit. Now a manufacturer is selling condoms in 60 sizes, in combinations of 10 lengths and nine circumferences.

2017-10-12.snippet: As the humanitarian crisis for Rohingya Muslims worsens, envoys are reluctant to criticize Aung San Suu Kyi even though they seem to have been frozen out.

2017-10-12.headline_main: Hands Tied by Old Hope, Diplomats in Myanmar Stay Silent

2017-10-12.abstract: Celebrated for his versatility as a percussionist, Mr. Tate “never thought of singing as a career,” but somehow it happened.
2017-10-12.snippet: Celebrated for his versatility as a percussionist, Mr. Tate “never thought of singing as a career,” but somehow it happened.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: Grady Tate, a jazz drummer who was known for his work with Peggy Lee, Quincy Jones, Ella Fitzgerald and many others and whose warm baritone led to a second career as a singer, died on Oct. 8 at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.
2017-10-12.headline_main: Grady Tate, Jazz Drummer Turned Vocalist, Dies at 85

2017-10-12.abstract: Our guide to new art shows, and some that will be closing soon.
2017-10-12.snippet: Our guide to new art shows, and some that will be closing soon.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: ART AND CHINA AFTER 1989: THEATER OF THE WORLD, at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum (through Jan 7, 2018). New York is still behind the curve in terms of familiarity with the explosion of contemporary art produced in China between the 1989 Tiananmen massacre and the 2008 Beijing Olympics. This dynamic, canon-affirming Guggenheim survey reprises much of what we already do know, but also adds fresh information about large group projects and, usefully, shift the focus away from auction-favored painting onto Conceptualism. (After protests from animal-right activists, three works in the show, including “Theater of the World” by Huang Yong Ping, appear in altered form.) (Holland Cotter)212-423-3500/guggenheim.org
2017-10-12.headline_main: Art and Museums in NYC This Week

2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: THOMAS ADÈS AND FRIENDS at Zankel Hall (Oct. 15, 3 p.m.). Thomas Adès is in New York for the buildup to the Metropolitan Opera’s performances of “The Exterminating Angel,” but here we find him as an accompanist for an afternoon of songs. Sally Matthews, Alice Coote, Iestyn Davies and Joseph Kaiser are the vocalists for works by Purcell (many of them transcribed by Mr. Adès), Schubert, Britten, Woolrich, Stravinsky and the composer-conductor-pianist himself.212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org

2017-10-12.abstract: The rise of the far-right could destroy the liberal societies that we know and love.
2017-10-12.snippet: The rise of the far-right could destroy the liberal societies that we know and love.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: On July 14, 2016, as French families strolled along Nice’s seafront promenade, a Tunisian man driving a large truck rammed into a crowd, killing 86 people. A month later, the mayor of nearby Cannes declared that “burkinis” — a catchall term for modest swimwear favored by many religious women — would be banned from the city’s beaches; a municipal official called the bathing suits “ostentatious clothing” expressing an “allegiance to terrorist movements that are at war with us.”

2017-10-12.snippet: Our guide to dance performances.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER at the David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center (Oct. 18-29, at various times). American Ballet Theater’s director, Kevin McKenzie, has said that one of his best moves in 25 years of leadership was hiring Alexei Ratmansky as choreographer-in-residence. This gala on Wednesday celebrates Mr. McKenzie’s quarter-century on the job and features the premiere of “Songs of Bukovina” by Mr. Ratmansky. Mr. McKenzie has also championed the choreographer Jessica Lang, who contributes a new work and whose previous company commission, “Her Notes,” is on Thursday’s program along with Mr. Ratmansky’s “Serenade After Plato’s Symposium,” Jerome Robbins’s “Other Dances” and Frederick Ashton’s “Symphonic Variations.” 212-496-0600, abt.org

2017-10-12.abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
2017-10-12.snippet: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: We’re nearing the season for ghost stories — or, in the case of William Alexander’s new middle-grade novel, “A Properly Unhaunted Place,” un-ghost stories, cautionary tales about what happens when we try too hard to put our history behind us. Eleanor Henderson’s “The Twelve-Mile Straight” and Josephine Rowe’s “A Loving, Faithful Animal” wrestle with the enduring trauma of violence over generations, and Alice McDermott’s “The Ninth Hour” draws narrative power from that perennial burden of Catholicism, shame. Two finalists for the National Book Awards appear on this week’s list: Frank Bidart’s collected poems, “Half-Light,” and Carmen Maria Machado’s debut collection of stories, “Her Body and Other Parties.” You have until the awards are announced on Nov. 15 to finish them. Go!
2017-10-12.headline_main: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week

2017-10-12.snippet: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: ‘ENCOUNTERS WITH THE NATURAL WORLD: SCIENCE FOR NANOS’ AT THE NEW YORK HALL OF SCIENCE (Oct. 14 at 2 p.m.) This cinema program is like a play date between art and science. And like any play date, it appeals to the adventurous young. Part of the Imagine Science Film Festival, which runs through Oct. 20, “Encounters” will present a dozen American and European shorts, whose settings range from a petri dish (Chloe Thomas’s “Dish Life”) to the International Space Station (Joseph Childs and Iro Tsavala’s “A Story From Space”). The selections also explore the ocean depths: “Polymer,” by Astrid Goldsmith, features an animated monster avenging plastic pollution, and “My Haggan Dream,” by the siblings Laura Sams and Rob Sams, follows a young girl’s investigation into sea turtles’ fragile future — and our own. 718-699-0005, imaginesciencefilms.org
2017-10-12.headline_main: Events for Children in NYC This Week

2017-10-12.abstract: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.
2017-10-12.snippet: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.
2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: ‘COMIN’ AT YA!: 3-D 35MM’ at the Quad Cinema (Oct. 13-19). Today’s 3-D movies use digital projection, but that stereoscopic effect was originally achieved by having two overlapping images projected from strips of film. The revival of 3-D cheese-fests in the 1980s afforded a rite of passage to some rising stars of the decade, including Molly Ringwald in “Spacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone 3-D” (Oct. 13), Dennis Quaid in “Jaws 3-D” (Oct. 15 and Oct. 17) and Demi Moore in “Parasite 3-D” (Oct. 18). But the attraction of a retrospective like the Quad’s is a chance to see rare formats in action. Arch Oboler’s “The Bubble” (Oct. 14), from 1966, was recently restored for digital projection, but the Quad will present it in its original 35-millimeter “Space-Vision.” Instead of two projectors running simultaneously — one for each eye — as was the practice in the 1950s, Space-Vision achieved the 3-D effect using one projector and one film strip with two images in every frame. This will be the first known screening of the original roadshow version since Mr. Oboler cut the film by more than 20 minutes in 1968, says Robert Furmanek, founder and chief executive of the 3-D Film Archive. 212-255-2243, quadcinema.com
2017-10-12.headline_main: Film Series in NYC This Week

2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: AGAINST ME! at Brooklyn Steel (Oct. 14, 8 p.m.). Against Me! thrives in the spaces where the personal and the political collide with enough force to make noise — preferably loud noise. The band, led by the intense, charismatic singer Laura Jane Grace, has been at the creative forefront of punk rock for well over a decade, but feels particularly crucial now: In an era of rampant frustration with American society, Ms. Grace makes screaming your truth feel like a vital act of protest. With Bleached and the Dirty Nil. bowerypresents.com/brooklyn-steel

2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: There’s no shortage of images from New York City’s subway system, with millions of smartphone-toting riders each day. Yet for much of the last century, until 1994, photography in the city’s rapid transit system was illegal (though it was a spottily enforced offense). In the late 1930s — soon after the city imposed its ban — Helen Levitt, a young Bensonhurst native, apprenticed with Walker Evans as he photographed unsuspecting commuters.

2017-10-12.lead_paragraph: A father-son lunch turns into an uncomfortable negotiation in this scene from “The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected).” The scene features Ben Stiller as Matthew meeting his dad, Harold (Dustin Hoffman), for lunch, with a secret plan to bring up the business of trying to settle his father’s estate. He brings along an associate, Gabe (Matthew Shear), and Harold doesn’t take the meeting so well. Mr. Baumbach shot the scene at a Brooklyn restaurant, where he and his crew capture much of the scene in a long take. In a recent interview in New York, the director discussed how he chose the location for the scene and what made it a challenge. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

2017-10-13.abstract: We talk about sexual misconduct at the hands of the powerful, and about how our world has outpaced the dystopia of ‘Blade Runner.’
2017-10-13.snippet: We talk about sexual misconduct at the hands of the powerful, and about how our world has outpaced the dystopia of ‘Blade Runner.’
2017-10-13.lead_paragraph: It’s our season finale! We’ve spent our second season keeping a critical eye on the unreality of America and dissecting the systems of power that uphold the status quo. Last week, a series of news articles reported that Harvey Weinstein, one of the most powerful movie producers in Hollywood, has been accused of sexually harrassing women for decades. Twitter is ablaze with other women and men sharing their own stories of sexual misconduct at the hands of the powerful, spawning conversations about power and fame, privilege and punishment. The aftermath has raised questions about the commonality of harassment — and has forced us to confront our own complacency. We were compelled to talk about the cultural petri dish that allows assault and abuse to perpetuate and about what might be changing, socially and technologically, that is encouraging survivors to come forward. We also discuss the recently released “Blade Runner 2049” which somehow felt lacking, as if science fiction can’t keep up with the reality of the moment we’re living through. And before we sign off for a few months, we relive some of our favorite moments from this season. Thank you for listening, and we’ll talk to you soon!
2017-10-13.headline_main: Still Processing: Harvey Weinstein and Our Unreal Reality

2017-10-13.abstract: Make sure your things look well-cared for. Tell the story if you have a specific, compelling monetary need.
2017-10-13.snippet: Make sure your things look well-cared for. Tell the story if you have a specific, compelling monetary need.
2017-10-13.lead_paragraph: “Think of us as a bank of last resort,” says Lou Tansky, the owner of Uncle Ben’s Pawn Shop in Cleveland. To pawn something, you must be an adult with valid identification, and the item must have some value as collateral. You don’t need good credit, income or a bank account. Commonly pawned items include jewelry, electronics, musical instruments and firearms, but the possibilities are wide-ranging: Tansky has accepted a pocketknife and knows a broker who was approached about pawning a Learjet. Be aware of state-specific prohibitions; in Delaware, for example, it is illegal to pawn artificial limbs and wheelchairs. “I don’t want anybody’s stuff,” Tansky says. Most brokers make the bulk of their income from interest, not from reselling things.
2017-10-13.headline_main: How to Pawn Valuables

2017-10-13.abstract: Brooklyn’s famously filthy canal is getting cleaned up. A building boom is coming. And not everyone is happy.

2017-10-13.lead_paragraph: “Welcome to Venice Jerko.” The greeting is painted in three-foot-high letters on a brick wall along Brooklyn’s legendarily polluted Gowanus Canal, right across from the canal’s first luxury high-rise and its new waterfront promenade.
2017-10-13.headline_main: Can Gowanus Survive Its Renaissance?

2017-10-13.abstract: For this issue, a look at the struggle to help anxious teenagers.
2017-10-13.snippet: For this issue, a look at the struggle to help anxious teenagers.
2017-10-13.lead_paragraph: Jake Silverstein, editor in chief: “We dramatically cropped the portrait of Jillian, a teenager in Benoit Denizet-Lewis’s article about adolescent anxiety, to make clear that she was meant to represent not just herself but all kids who suffer this way. We also liked the way that the weight of that heavy black rectangle looming above her seemed to nicely capture the sense of helplessness many of these teens feel.”

2017-10-13.abstract: The editor in chief of The New York Times Magazine sits down with the grant winner, who writes for the magazine about segregation in housing and education.
2017-10-13.snippet: The editor in chief of The New York Times Magazine sits down with the grant winner, who writes for the magazine about segregation in housing and education.
2017-10-13.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation announced the 24 recipients of its annual fellowship, often called the “genius grant,” which awards $625,000, no strings attached, to “exceptionally creative people” each year. Among those who received the unexpected phone call this year was Nikole Hannah-Jones, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, whose work, rooted in deeply researched historical insight, focuses on endemic racism in housing and education.
2017-10-13.headline_main: A Chat With MacArthur Genius Nikole Hannah-Jones

2017-10-13.snippet: In the wake of hurricanes Irma and Maria, a look at the destruction, bright spots and uncertain future.
2017-10-13.lead_paragraph: After an unforgiving start to the hurricane season, some idyllic Caribbean destinations are in the midst of a slow and arduous recovery that may take months, even years, while others are ready — or nearly ready — for the all-important holiday travel season.
2017-10-13.headline_main: The Recovery Process: Caribbean Tourism, Island by Island

2017-10-13.abstract: The Great River Road, the byway that runs next to the Mississippi River, was the organizing principle of a road trip that took a family through the history of this land.
2017-10-13.snippet: The Great River Road, the byway that runs next to the Mississippi River, was the organizing principle of a road trip that took a family through the history of this land.
2017-10-13.lead_paragraph: One Friday afternoon, we drove away from Chicago to look for rivers. The first one we came across was slender and manicured, like a path for floating golf carts. It followed the highway for a mile or two before turning away. Then came the real thing, the DuPage River, flowing fast and high with spring rain. We followed that for a while, heading toward our main destination: the Mississippi.
2017-10-13.headline_main: Along the Mississippi

2017-10-13.abstract: A plant conservationist from Syria and his colleagues are safeguarding seeds that might be crucial when more parts of the world become as hot and arid as the Middle East.
2017-10-13.snippet: A plant conservationist from Syria and his colleagues are safeguarding seeds that might be crucial when more parts of the world become as hot and arid as the Middle East.
2017-10-13.lead_paragraph: TERBOL, Lebanon — Ali Shehadeh, a seed hunter, opened the folders with the greatest of care. Inside each was a carefully dried and pressed seed pod: a sweet clover from Egypt, a wild wheat found only in northern Syria, an ancient variety of bread wheat. He had thousands of these folders stacked neatly in a windowless office, a precious herbarium, containing seeds foraged from across the hot, arid and increasingly inhospitable region known as the Fertile Crescent, the birthplace of farming.
2017-10-13.headline_main: How a Seed Bank, Almost Lost in Syria’s War, Could Help Feed a Warming Planet

2017-10-13.abstract: The cheerleaders at Howard, a historically black university, kneel during the national anthem before football games. Players don’t get the chance.
2017-10-13.snippet: The cheerleaders at Howard, a historically black university, kneel during the national anthem before football games. Players don’t get the chance.
2017-10-13.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few minutes before kickoff on Oct. 7 at Howard University’s Greene Stadium — about two miles from the White House — the public address announcer said, “We ask that you please rise as we honor the United States of America.” At the 50-yard-line, four members of the Air Force R.O.T.C. presented the colors.
2017-10-13.headline_main: Howard Cheerleaders Add Voices to the Anthem Debate by Taking a Knee
