2017-10-31.snippet: We know the most valuable players. But who are the most valuable barbers of the World Series?
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: After the Houston Astros first baseman Yulieski Gurriel belted a three-run homer against the Los Angeles Dodgers on Sunday, tying up Game 5 of the World Series, he tossed off his helmet. His eye-catching cut, called “La Piña” — the pineapple — for its tall, spiky sprout, received enthusiastic rubs and fluffs from his teammates as he crossed home plate and Houston’s Minute Maid Park reverberated with the excitement of fans.
2017-10-31.headline_main: The Freshest Astros Haircuts in Houston

2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Leslie Dowling motored down a narrow residential street beneath a leafy canopy, past small, tightly clustered houses from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with gable and hip roofs and broad front porches. Then there was a glimpse of something new — a modernist box of a house seemingly elevated in the treetops —before she twisted the steering wheel to enter a narrow driveway and slipped into a tiny carport beneath the structure.
2017-10-31.headline_main: A Modernist Box Among the Victorians

2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: On Nov. 2, 1967, a dozen or so of America’s most respected foreign policy mandarins assembled at the White House to meet with President Johnson and his top Vietnam advisers. While the president maintained a sternly optimistic public face on the war, the conflict was threatening to consume his Presidency, and so he sought the wisdom of these advisers, a virtual Mount Rushmore of America’s postwar foreign policy establishment.

2017-10-31.snippet: Gravity-defying furniture, performance art in the East Village, totes for travel and more.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: Born in Nebraska and raised on a ranch east of Reno, Nev., John Mason arrived in Los Angeles in 1949 curious about ceramics, a discipline that was then largely dismissed as a craft rather than a fine art. But Mason wasn’t deterred: He trained at the Otis and Chouinard art institutes under master ceramists Susan Peterson and Peter Voulkos, and was among the first artists to show at L.A.’s now-iconic Ferus Gallery, known for championing art that bridged the gap between high and low. (Warhol’s soup cans debuted there in 1962, as did John Altoon’s lyrical, quasi-Abstract Expressionist “Ocean Park” paintings.) In the decades since, the now-90-year-old Mason has become renowned for his simple geometric forms (spears, crosses and torqued pillars), which he fires in a room-size kiln in his downtown L.A. studio. An upcoming solo show at Albertz Benda gallery in N.Y.C. will highlight some of his towering columnar works, along with more intimately proportioned, pedestal-friendly sculptures, most of them never previously seen. Some unfold vertically like the gills of an accordion, swiveling effortlessly up from their bases; others stand stoically, their smooth surfaces defined by crisp edges. Glazed in rich, earthy hues like turquoise and burnt umber, they are arresting reminders of an artist who superseded the technical limits of clay — as well as the superficial opposition of art and craft, paving the way for later artists such as Sterling Ruby and Brie Ruais. — LIZ HIRSCH
2017-10-31.headline_main: A Shortlist of What We Like Right Now

2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: PASTA FLYER When you promise miracles like a good plate of pasta in mere minutes, you have to get it right. That effort is what has taken the chef, Mark Ladner, many more months than he anticipated to engineer his concept. Now, with skills honed in the serious precincts of Del Posto, after time in some of the earthier Batali-Bastianich properties like Otto, he’s ready. Enter the restaurant up some stairs, and you go straight to the counter where the action is. “It’s a completely new design, and it’s much better,” he said. Last spring, poised to open, he and his business partner, Nastassia Lopez, decided their kitchen plan wasn’t working, so they had the whole thing rebuilt to make the pasta assembly line more efficient, always with an eye on the stopwatch. Mr. Ladner’s combination of speed and quality at a low price involves a freezing method. He offers three types of pastas with a basic marinara sauce for $6 to $7; adding pesto or meat costs another dollar, and 50 cents gets you a topping like cheese. Beverages include wine. To one side in the high-ceilinged space are plush banquettes, tables and chairs: 510 Avenue of the Americas (13th Street), no phone, pastaflyer.com.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Pasta Flyer, Mark Ladner’s Latest, Opens in Greenwich Village

2017-10-31.abstract: The real Frank Serpico proves to be a compelling figure in a documentary that picks up where the classic Hollywood film left off.
2017-10-31.snippet: The real Frank Serpico proves to be a compelling figure in a documentary that picks up where the classic Hollywood film left off.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: This movie’s intention is in its title. The documentary “Frank Serpico” fills out an American classic that is now almost 45 years old. “Serpico,” the 1973 movie directed by Sidney Lumet and starring Al Pacino, was an adaptation of a book by Peter Maas about a New York City police officer who fought corruption in the ranks and got, among other things, a bullet in the head for his trouble. The real-life subject is now 81 years old, whippet-thin, and a storyteller and self-examiner of no small gifts.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Review: ‘Frank Serpico’ Updates the Story of the Man Behind a Classic Movie

2017-10-31.abstract: Her story went viral when she scooped a local homicide story. Now, she stars in a children’s book series based on her reporting experiences.
2017-10-31.snippet: Her story went viral when she scooped a local homicide story. Now, she stars in a children’s book series based on her reporting experiences.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: The first book in the “Hilde Cracks the Case” series opens with 9-year-old Hilde Lysiak outside her local police station in the town of Selinsgrove, Pa., following up on a tip about a break-in on Orange Street. The on-duty officer refuses to divulge any information, but if she’s going to break the story in her newspaper, The Orange Street News, she has to investigate using six basic reporting questions: Who? What? Where? When? Why? How?

2017-10-31.snippet: 180 the Store showcases brands represented by the public relations firm Williamson, which happens to live upstairs.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: It’s no surprise that fashion boutiques hire publicists, but how many publicists open their own boutique? That’s the back story to 180 the Store in TriBeCa, which was opened by Denise Williamson in the same building, 180 Duane Street, where she runs her fashion P.R. agency, Williamson PR. The idea is to showcase her clients (mostly Japanese labels including Visvim and Nanamica), as well as other brands that she adores. The 2,500-square-foot space is constantly in flux, and is used regularly for events and pop-up installations.
2017-10-31.headline_main: A TriBeCa Store With Built-In P.R. Buzz

2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: Christine McPherson, who prefers to be called Lady Bird — it’s her given name, she insists, in the sense that “it’s given to me, by me” — is a senior at a Catholic girls’ high school. Sister Sarah Joan (Lois Smith), the principal, has read Lady Bird’s college application essay. “It’s clear how much you love Sacramento,” Sister Sarah remarks. This comes as a surprise, both to Lady Bird and the viewer, who is by now aware of Lady Bird’s frustration with her hometown.

The stationmaster bicycles ahead of them to issue a warning at the watering hole; the residents begin to whisper. It’s the wedding day of the son of the town clerk, who doesn’t want any trouble with elections coming up. The wedding itself seems like a shaky affair, with an uneasy groom and a bride whose previous fiancé is still hovering.

And then Bonnie is pulled into an alleyway, where she is brutally raped by a stranger.

2017-10-31.abstract: Some of the most compelling erotic art is being made by a nearly forgotten generation of women artists now in their 70s, 80s and 90s.
2017-10-31.snippet: Some of the most compelling erotic art is being made by a nearly forgotten generation of women artists now in their 70s, 80s and 90s.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: THIS SUMMER IN LOS ANGELES, a hairy, phallic-looking screw painted by Judith Bernstein extended across 180 feet of the exterior of Venus gallery in Boyle Heights. This month at MoMA PS1 in Queens, men and women stripped down to their underwear and rubbed each other with raw fish in a video by Carolee Schneemann. And in London, pink double-headed phalluses bloomed from cacti in Renate Bertlmann’s sculptures at the Frieze art fair.
2017-10-31.headline_main: The Feminist Pioneers Making Provocative Art About Sex

A “record album interpretation,” directed by Kate Valk, the production has returned with its original cast of Eric Berryman (who conceived the show), Jasper McGruder and Philip Moore. 2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: No one would find the prospect of posthumous fame more appalling than the photographer Vivian Maier. In life, she fanatically concealed her traces: She liked strong bolts on her doors, fake names (she had at least three in rotation) and what seemed to be a spurious French accent. She rarely discussed or shared her work. Many assumed she was homeless.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Vivian Maier, Through a Clearer Lens

2017-10-31.abstract: A level internet playing field lets them, and everyone else, bypass powerful gatekeepers.
2017-10-31.snippet: A level internet playing field lets them, and everyone else, bypass powerful gatekeepers.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: Somewhere at a comedy club, a new comedian is about to hit the stage for the first time. She will bring with her the modern tool of the trade: her cellphone, equipped with the notes she has typed, a recording app, and five minutes of material that isn’t worth all that technology. This set is going to bomb. Hard. But she will repeat this process — night in, night out, until over time, that five-minute performance becomes tighter and more polished. Eventually, she’ll ask a friend to use a phone to record a set. And that night she will kill. Utterly destroy the room. That will be the first time she uploads footage of herself performing to the internet. Her life will never be the same.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Net Neutrality: Why Artists and Activists Can’t Afford to Lose It

2017-10-31.snippet: Connecticut has gone months without a budget as lawmakers wrestled over how to close a $3.5 billion deficit and sought to address mounting financial struggles.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut approved a two-year, $40.2 billion budget on Tuesday that includes spending cuts and a variety of measures meant to improve a dire financial situation and end a stalemate that forced the state to operate without a budget for 123 days.

2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Justice announced Tuesday that Exxon Mobil will pay $2.5 million in fines for flaring gases at eight plants along the Gulf Coast. Agency officials said the announcement was evidence of the Trump administration’s commitment to enforcing the nation’s environmental laws.

2017-10-31.snippet: Msgr. Harry J. Byrne, once an official of the Archdiocese of New York, regularly showed people the disturbing images, the Bronx district attorney said.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: A 96-year-old retired priest who was once a high-ranking official of the Archdiocese of New York was arraigned in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on Tuesday on charges of possessing child pornography. The pictures, which were on his computer, were of girls ages 8 to 14 years old performing sex acts with men or posing naked, the Bronx district attorney said.

2017-10-31.snippet: Technical troubles that took the Common App portal offline for two hours Monday night were met with anxiety and mordant humor by students and college officials.

2017-10-31.abstract: Eight people were killed and at least 12 were injured when the driver of a rented truck drove down a bike lane. Many details remain unclear.
2017-10-31.snippet: Eight people were killed and at least 12 were injured when the driver of a rented truck drove down a bike lane. Many details remain unclear.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: Eight people were killed on Tuesday, and 12 injured when a rented pickup truck plowed down a bike lane that runs along the West Side Highway in Lower Manhattan, officials said. The pickup smashed into a school bus before the driver, Sayfullo Saipov, a New Jersey truck driver who immigrated from Uzbekistan, jumped out and was shot by a police officer, the authorities said.
2017-10-31.headline_main: What We Know and Don’t Know About the Manhattan Terror Attack

2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: With just weeks before Reza Zarrab, a Turkish gold trader who has been charged in Manhattan with conspiring to violate the United States sanctions on Iran, is to go on trial, his lawyers have given every indication that he may be prepared to plead guilty.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Signs of Possible Guilty Plea in Turkish Gold Trader Case

2017-10-31.abstract: Our tortured attempt to find some kind of balance on whether it was right to enslave African-Americans wasn’t limited to the Three-Fifths Compromise.
2017-10-31.snippet: Our tortured attempt to find some kind of balance on whether it was right to enslave African-Americans wasn’t limited to the Three-Fifths Compromise.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: In an interview with Laura Ingraham on Fox News last night, the White House chief of staff, John Kelly, said “the lack of an ability to compromise led to the Civil War,” a statement that would shock, among others, the founding fathers. After spirited debates at the 1787 Constitutional Convention, they included Article 1, Section 2, Paragraph 3 in our Constitution, which said each slave, for legislative representation and taxation purposes, counted as three-fifths of a person. That provision is known as the Three-Fifths Compromise, a term that clearly states that Northerners and Southerners were, in fact, quite able to reach weird compromises on slavery.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Slavery Thrived on Compromise, John Kelly

2017-10-31.abstract: Elite campuses have too few grown-up students.
2017-10-31.snippet: Elite campuses have too few grown-up students.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: Usually, when a demographic group is significantly underrepresented on elite college campuses, we consider it a problem. But there is one such problem that almost no one seems to notice or care much about. Nearly 30 percent of college undergraduates are adults, defined by the United States Department of Education as 25 years old or older. But at Stanford, the share of undergraduates who are adults is 1.2 percent; at Yale, 0.7 percent; at Princeton, 0.6 percent; at the University of Chicago, 0.2 percent.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Let’s Waste College on the Old

2017-10-31.abstract: The Bulldogs (8-0) were followed by Alabama (8-0), Notre Dame (7-1) and Clemson (7-1) in the playoff committee’s initial rankings.
2017-10-31.snippet: The Bulldogs (8-0) were followed by Alabama (8-0), Notre Dame (7-1) and Clemson (7-1) in the playoff committee’s initial rankings.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: Defying The Associated Press’s poll and much recent history, the initial College Football Playoff rankings placed the undefeated Georgia Bulldogs (8-0) in the top spot, one above the undefeated Southeastern Conference colossus Alabama (8-0).
2017-10-31.headline_main: Georgia Tops First College Football Playoff Rankings

2017-10-31.abstract: After treatment for H. pylori infection, people who took proton pump inhibitors were at increased risk of stomach cancer.
2017-10-31.snippet: After treatment for H. pylori infection, people who took proton pump inhibitors were at increased risk of stomach cancer.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: People who carry the stomach bacteria known as Helicobacter pylori are at increased risk for ulcers and stomach cancer. But even when antibiotic treatment has eliminated the bacterium, stomach cancer may still arise. A new study suggests that one reason may be the long-term use of proton pump inhibitors, or P.P.I.s, acid-reducing medicines sold under brand names such as Prilosec and Prevacid.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Stomach Cancer Risk

2017-10-31.abstract: We have a narrow-view president in a big-picture world.
2017-10-31.snippet: We have a narrow-view president in a big-picture world.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: It is easy to ignore the recent story of four U.S. servicemen killed in Niger, the giant state in central Africa, because the place is so remote and the circumstances still so murky. That would be a mistake. Niger highlights a much larger problem — just how foolish, how flat-out dumb President Trump is behaving.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Trump, Niger and Connecting the Dots

2017-10-31.abstract: Millions of Americans suffer hearing loss, but too few of us do anything about it. That has to change.
2017-10-31.snippet: Millions of Americans suffer hearing loss, but too few of us do anything about it. That has to change.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: If I do my job right, this column might actually change your life. More important, it might change the lives of the people you love.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Glasses Are Cool. Why Aren’t Hearing Aids?

2017-10-31.abstract: In an era of bigger squads and multimillion-dollar specialists, Champions League managers are rediscovering the value of a pro who can play multiple positions.
2017-10-31.snippet: In an era of bigger squads and multimillion-dollar specialists, Champions League managers are rediscovering the value of a pro who can play multiple positions.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: In the year that Bobby Robson coached Barcelona, 1996-97, he was not short of players to praise. His defense was marshaled by Laurent Blanc, his midfield controlled by Pep Guardiola and his attack spearheaded by Ronaldo, the greatest talent of his generation.
2017-10-31.headline_main: In Praise of Soccer’s Jack-of-All-Trades, Now Making a Comeback

2017-10-31.abstract: Even failure has meaning, and the lessons — for fans, too — are sometimes more valuable.
2017-10-31.snippet: Even failure has meaning, and the lessons — for fans, too — are sometimes more valuable.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: Baseball is a series of definitive moments, but none are quite like the final out of the World Series. It’s recorded, and we all, players and fans, claim instant perspective. Win the World Series and everything you experienced before it has led, inevitably and majestically, to this moment. Even previous failure has new meaning, and previous success has been bottled. More important, winning made it worth it all, whatever “it” was — the rehab from Tommy John surgery, the 111 losses four years ago, the boos.
2017-10-31.headline_main: The Crucial Role of World Series Losers

2017-10-31.abstract: Some users received alerts on Tuesday that they had violated Google’s terms of service, and were subsequently stopped from accessing or sharing their documents.
2017-10-31.snippet: Some users received alerts on Tuesday that they had violated Google’s terms of service, and were subsequently stopped from accessing or sharing their documents.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: Google Docs threw some users for a loop on Tuesday when the service suddenly locked them out of their documents for violating Google’s terms of service. The weird part? The documents were innocuous. The alerts were caused by a glitch, but they served as a stark reminder that not much is truly private in the cloud.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Google Docs Glitch That Locked Out Users Underscores Privacy Concerns

2017-10-31.abstract: As he closed in on the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, Donald J. Trump named foreign policy advisers who are now under scrutiny for Russia ties.
2017-10-31.snippet: As he closed in on the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, Donald J. Trump named foreign policy advisers who are now under scrutiny for Russia ties.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One lasted only 24 days as President Trump’s national security adviser, done in by his lack of candor about conversations he had with the Russian ambassador. Another has been hauled in front of a federal grand jury investigating Russia’s interference in the election.
2017-10-31.headline_main: Ongoing Trump Migraine: His Initial Foreign Policy Team

2017-10-31.abstract: A day after the first charges from the investigation into Russian election interference, the president seethed, his party ducked and the opposition chortled.
2017-10-31.snippet: A day after the first charges from the investigation into Russian election interference, the president seethed, his party ducked and the opposition chortled.
2017-10-31.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The president seethed with resentment, his party ducked for cover and the opposition chortled with glee. Lawyers counseled clients. Lawmakers tried to change the subject. Campaign veterans fretted that colleagues may be wearing a wire. And everyone wondered about a guy named George Papadopoulos.
2017-10-31.headline_main: A Capital Consumed by Talk of Scandal and Suspicion
